—That is a very bad practice to follow.

—The previous Government established the practice. I remember complaining about it when I was on the other side of the chamber, and I could not get a direct answer from the Minister responsible. We have fallen into the practice of duty Ministers having to accept the responsibility for portfolios of which they have no knowledge. It is a very difficult situation. We have had an extensive scrutiny of the Estimates by the various Estimates committees. We are now going through the same process again.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen The Hon A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —On examining the Hansard record of the Estimates Committee hearing, I notice that Senator Durack raised all these matters as he has indicated, at that hearing. In particular, he asked questions on appointments in Perth. He was given this answer by Senator Gareth Evans, who, after all, was representing the Attorney-General:

SPEECH.PARA: I think that is a matter for the Attorney-General to answer. I am not in a position to do so on his behalf. I do not think that it is an appropriate matter for the officer.
Senator Durack then asked this question:
Perhaps you will take that on notice?
Senator Gareth Evans then said:
I will take it on notice and see what Mr Bowen might be inclined to say.

It appears that Senator Durack is of the view that he has not received a satisfactory answer. No doubt, the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has taken the question on notice and will answer it when he is ready. That is nothing new. It has been par for the course as long as I have been a senator. Ministers of Senator Durack's Government did not answer questions at the convenience of an individual senator, be it a Government or an Opposition senator. Governments have taken their time to answer questions, whatever political party has been in power. The Attorney-General, for his own reasons, obviously has not responded to Senator Durack's question. I am not competent and certainly the departmental officers are not competent to reply on matters which are the individual responsibility of a Minister and the responsibility of the Government of the day.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I suppose that what we have ended up with is the fact that the Attorney-General does not have any answer to the question that he has been asked. Apparently the departmental officers present in the chamber have not been informed of the answer by their own Minister, despite the fact that that question was asked over two months ago. That is a sorry commentary on the Attorney-General, but I suppose we should not be very surprised at it, having seen his performance generally. In those circumstances, I will not proceed to postpone the proceedings any further because clearly nobody except the Attorney-General can answer my questions. I simply note that he treats the Parliament in this cavalier way. I might say that the very firm tradition in this place has been that when questions are asked at Estimates committee hearings that cannot be answered, the answers are provided before the Estimates committees report to the Senate. Not only has this question not been answered within that time frame and following that tradition; it has not been answered now when the matter is being debated in the Committee of the Whole. The Attorney-General will obviously have to wear the responsibility for that totally cavalier and, I believe, insulting attitude towards this Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: Another matter to which I want to refer could really be dealt with under the same heading as the previous question I referred to; namely, Division 170 dealing with courts and tribunals. It was agreed at the hearing of Estimates Committee E that the questions I wished to ask on travelling allowances of judges and statutory officers could be dealt with under that heading because they had a very close relevance to it. In fact, those estimates are not covered in Division 170 but are dealt with under the special appropriations for the Department.

I note that Senator Walsh, who is presently acting for the Attorney-General in this place, is with us now. I am sure that he will have done a lot of homework on this subject. He is so interested in the portfolio that I know he will be in a very strong position to answer my questions and if not he will at least be particularly interested in what I have to say. A matter which I find very disturbing indeed relates to the estimates for travelling allowances for High Court judges, Federal Court judges, and Family Court judges. I shall give honourable senators an example of the problems that we faced on the Estimates Committee. One item provided $67,084 to cover travelling allowances for High Court judges. As there are seven High Court judges, that amounted to a total travelling allowance figure-that is an allowance for overnight travel-for each of these judges of $9,600 per annum. That has to be considered in the context of the fact that five of the seven High Court judges receive a lump sum to cover travel from their home States to Canberra. I think that they get a lump sum of about $10,000 for the time that they spend in Canberra. We know that the High Court spends most of its time sitting in Canberra. So some $67,000 was allowed to cover travel by any of those five judges who live outside Canberra when the High Court sits somewhere other than their home base and for those two High Court judges who live in Canberra when they travel to places outside Canberra. It was really inconceivable that $9,600 should be allowed on average for each of the seven judges. I asked some questions about that. The Senate received a staggering reply in the supplementary answers that were provided, to which I have been referring. I asked the question:
Again we do not have any figures for the travelling allowance--
that is, the travelling allowance payable to justices of the High Court of Australia-
for 1984-85. We have an estimate for 1985-86 of $67,000. Have you got a figure for 1984-85?
The reply that I received was:
In 1984-85 expenditure of $31,098 was incurred by Justices of the High Court for travelling allowance.

So twice the amount that was estimated for the past financial year has been estimated for the current financial year. I asked the same question about Federal Court judges travelling allowance. Mind you, there were something like 28 judges. I was told that $284,369 was claimed for this year whereas last year it was $145,000. In relation to Family Court judges, this year $303,323 is being claimed for travelling allowances whereas last year, on inquiry, I was told that it was $157,000. So that figure has nearly doubled again. I do not know whether the Attorney-General's Department in its estimating follows the principle of thinking of a number and doubling it, but it looks very like it. The Deputy Secretary to the Department, in a letter of 4 October covering all of this further information, says:

the estimates for travelling allowance under Special Appropriations for the High Court, Federal Court and Family Court, when compared with the figures now provided for the preceding year, show increases too great to be fully explained by the factors I mentioned during the hearing.

At least that was a recognition that was long overdue because these allowances were under question. How could such increases be required? The answers given at the hearing were quite inadequate. Mr Glare, the Deputy Secretary, on reflection has finally come to that conclusion as well. At the Estimates Committee hearing very strenuous efforts were made by officers of the Department to justify these incredible increases. I suggest that Senator Walsh, who is at the table, has a fertile field for the future as Minister for Finance in querying some of these estimates because here we have twice the amount being claimed as was expended in the previous year. The officers tried to justify those incredible increases and we now have the admission by the Deputy Secretary of the Department that they are too great to be fully explained by the factors mentioned during the hearing. This was his conclusion:

These estimates appear to have been subject to estimating error. Because the travel which gives rise to travelling allowance claims is constrained by other items, the effect is that there will be savings under the three travelling allowance items.

I hope there will be very considerable savings, about 50 per cent of the amounts that have been claimed. I do not propose to ask any further questions about these matters, but I do think that they reveal an incredible approach to the estimating of judges' travelling allowances. What concerns me is that these matters, which are on the public record, can lead to a very widespread misunderstanding about the amount of travel that judges undertake, and to questions about extravagances by judges, which of course would be quite unjustified, as the Deputy Secretary of the Department now admits. Over the past year there has been a great deal of focus on the judiciary. At such a time to have outlandish claims appearing for travel by judges of the High Court of Australia in particular-twice as much as for the year before-would indicate, I think, that there is something questionable about the travel that they may be undertaking. But we now find that that is due simply to what the Department calls `estimating error'. Although I am pleased that that admission has now been made, I believe it is a very serious and a most unfortunate error and one which should never have occurred. I hope it will never occur again. I also expect, at the next Estimates committee hearing, to be advised about what degree of savings is expected in respect of judicial travel. I put all concerned on notice now that next year I will certainly be asking questions about that to ensure that these amounts that will presumably be voted for by the Parliament-as the officer says, nothing can be done about it now as they are the figures-will show considerable savings.

There is another matter about which I am not satisfied, and that is the travelling allowance claimed for the Solicitor-General. I preface my remarks in relation to this by giving some facts. The travelling allowance claimed for the Solicitor-General amounts to $32,000. At the daily rate of allowance for the Solicitor-General, under the new Remuneration Tribunal guidelines, that amounts to about 200 days in which travelling allowance can be claimed by him. That is a very large item when we consider that the Solicitor-General has been required by the Government to be based in and to live in Canberra. His arrangements have differed from those of his predecessor who lived in Sydney and who used to come to Canberra on several days most weeks and who may well have accumulated a large travel expenditure as a result. But the new Solicitor-General is required to live in Canberra and has been given an allowance for living here, which I think amounts to about $10,000 a year under the new Remuneration Tribunal guidelines. That is already provided for by a statutory provision. The Canberra allowance is in addition to that; it is a separate item. So, in addition to the Canberra allowance of $10,000, apparently an amount of $32,000 has been allowed for his travel outside Canberra. Some information has been provided as to his requirements to travel around Australia--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Durack, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vigor Sen D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have three simple questions; one relating to the area of class actions, the second relating to the proposed small claims and residential tenancies tribunal in the Australian Capital Territory and the third relating to the Freedom of Information Act. In February 1977 the Australian Law Reform Commission received references on standing and class actions. Is there any indication when the final report from this reference will be ready? Why are such delays occurring when annual reports for each of the past few years have said that the final document was imminent. Does the Government intend to continue waiting for the report from the Law Reform Commission before developing policies in this area? In 1980-these matters relate to one another-a working party suggested that small claims and residential tenancies tribunals be established in the Australian Capital Territory. Some time ago there was a report of a draft ordinance making its way through the bureaucratic system. Can the Minister inform us when the working party's suggestions are likely to be acted upon? Why is it that Australian Capital Territory matters always seem to take so long to settle?

SPEECH.PARA: My last question is: In the light of the nearly half of the requests for internal revenue under the freedom of information legislation are at least in part successful, and a fair proportion of matters that are taken to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are also successful, does the Government intend to require agencies to break down their freedom of information costs into three categories; first instance, internal revenue and Administrative Appeal Tribunal-so that their performance and especially their compliance with the spirit of the freedom of information legislation can be measured by both the public and by the Parliament?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that the Australian Law Reform Commission has nearly completed its reference on class actions. I will have to take the second question on notice. The third question relating to freedom of information and whether the administrative costs or the costs involving the Administrative Appeals Tribunal are separated I understand is under review. If the Attorney-General (Mr Lionel Bowen) has anything to add, I will supply that.

SPEECH.PARA: In Senator Durack's earlier comments, there was some implicit criticism of the Department of Finance for not scrutinising the Estimates sufficiently or picking up an estimating error. I know that in some cases the Department of Finance does challenge figures of that nature put up by various departments and sometimes obtains the agreement of departments to vary the estimates which have been submitted; but I guess it cannot do everything. Perhaps the trouble with the Attorney-General's Department is that it contains too many lawyers who frequently do not seem to think that money matters very much. I have nothing else to add. What I have not been able to supply to Senator Vigor, I will endeavour to get later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just wish to return to the comments I was making about the travelling allowance provided to the Solicitor-General. He is based in Canberra; the Government wants him in Canberra and there is good reason for that. Obviously, his main work is in Canberra but, admittedly, he has to travel around for many other meetings and conferences and, I suppose, appearances in court. The Department has provided, by way of example, some indication of the sort of travel he does, which is all perfectly well known. Even under the widest, most generous calculations, it would not be likely that he would be away for what would be about 200 nights. Presumably, if he is away for only part of a day he does not receive the full amount, although I am not sure about that. On the face of it, there appears to be the same sort of gross overcalculation of travelling allowance estimated for the Solicitor-General as there has been for judges. I do not want to say any more than that. Three errors have already been admitted. I wonder whether the Department has had another look at this item and whether it will now indicate that that is an accurate or semi-accurate estimate, or whether it falls within the same category as the estimates made for the Federal judges.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
That further consideration of the votes for the Department of Resources and Energy be resumed.
Department of Resources and Energy
Proposed expenditure, $171,530,000

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) whether he has replies to the questions I asked earlier. I asked two things of particular significance. In the three years of the Hawke Government and at Estimates Committees, is it not a fact that the Minister gave assurances that there were no vital or highly significant radioactive problems at the atomic test sites that were not being dealt with? Is it a fact that each time I questioned the Government, it gave reassurances about the maintenance of those sites? In view of the fact that a bibliography of tests on flora and fauna is given in the Estimates Committee list, does that bibliography confirm that there were no vital defects in flora and fauna at any of those sites over the years covered by that bibliography?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not recall precisely what I said in response to questions about Maralinga on every occasion they were asked. In the last few years such questions were asked of me rather than of the present Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans). I do remember questions on flora and fauna. To my knowledge, there was no evidence of any sort of genetic ill effects on the flora and fauna in the area concerned. In a more general sense, while I do not recall precisely what I said on every occasion, I did certainly report to the Senate at least once that fragments of plutonium had been discovered at some of the test sites and that, therefore, of course none of those sites could be regarded as absolutely safe, at least for permanent occupation or possibly even for transitory occupation. Action was taken, I think in 1984, to fence off the most sensitive areas. I do not think it would be accurate or reasonable to say that there were absolutely no hazards in that area under all conceivable circumstances. On the evidence available to it at the time, the Government took commonsense action to ensure that the public interest was reasonably protected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I therefore ask the Minister whether, from his recollection and from the knowledge of the Government, anything was left undone that it was necessary to do to protect health from any radioactive materials at any of the test sites?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Fallible judgments are involved in answering a question such as that. For example, it was demonstrated last year that fragments of plutonium were in the area. Since some fragments were found, it is a reasonable assumption that smaller fragments were also present. However, whether an attempt should be made, for example, to remove the first few inches of topsoil from a significant area of land of 50 or 100 acres or whether it would be better to fence off that area are matters of judgment to which no definitive answer can really be given. I take this opportunity to say that, although it is frequently not recognised, almost everything has a price. Among other things, any government would have to consider the cost which may be incurred in any clean-up operation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I recognise that the Minister cannot speak with the clearest recollection now, but I ask him to seek from his officials, and let me have in due course, an answer to my question about the bibliography, to confirm his recollection and mine that there was nothing significant in the tests. I ask that because at Estimates Committee E I was advised by the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) that no testing of flora or fauna was made by the McClelland Royal Commission into British Nuclear Tests in Australia between 1953 and 1963, so any information would be from prior to that time. Will the Minister check with his officials on answers given over the three years by both Ministers? I acknowledge that he gave full and frank answers during his term. I acknowledge that he drew attention to particles, particularly of plutonium, built up by dust. I acknowledge that evidence was given of fencing and fencing off. Fundamentally, however, what I am asking is: Did the Government, in that knowledge, regard what it was doing then as being basically effective, basically being the reasonable thing to do in the light of the knowledge at hand? Will the Minister get that information if he does not have it now?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer is yes, the information requested can, I think, be provided, and I shall endeavour to do so. Principally, the decisions about what was a reasonable thing to do, I suppose, were made by me. On the evidence available at the time, I thought, and still think, that the actions taken were reasonable actions. However, it should be borne in mind that what was thought to be a reasonable exposure to radiation in the early 1950s is no longer thought to be a reasonable exposure to radiation in the 1980s. Whether the McClelland Commission has added significantly, or at all, to the store of knowledge which was available at the time that I made those decisions, I do not know; but that is something which I expect will be known within the next few weeks.

SPEECH.PARA: On the question of genetic mutations, and the bibliography to which Senator Sir John Carrick referred, at that stage at least, certainly no evidence was brought to my knowledge that there had been any genetic mutations of plants or animals in the area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that reply. I asked a question on item 10 relating to energy conservation and in so doing drew attention to the fact that according to energy projections by the Department back in 1982 the growth of petroleum energy in Australia would be slowed down and would be only 0.5 per cent per year throughout the rest of this decade. I drew attention to the statement in the journal of the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association which said that Australian petroleum energy consumption is growing at nearly 2 per cent, and that is ahead of the world, compared with America at 0.6 per cent. I ask whether the Government had any comment on the fact that its consumption, if these figures are correct, is very considerably wide of the target of conservation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not know whether Senator Gareth Evans would have any comment on that question. There is one point that could be made: Although the ratio is not 1:1, there is, of course, some correlation between the rate of economic growth and energy consumption. Given that in the last 2 1/2 years Australia has had, by historic Australian standards and particularly by the standards of the last decade or so, a very high rate of economic growth, it must be expected that that high rate of economic growth must have some influence on the growth in petroleum energy consumption. Otherwise, I am not entirely familiar with this area any more; I shall see whether Senator Gareth Evans has any comment to make on the question.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister check the figures I have given in due course? When he talks about the high rate of economic growth, will he keep in mind that the American figure that I have given is an annual growth of 0.6 per cent in petroleum consumption and that America has had fairly consistent growth. Whilst I am on that subject, perhaps I may remind the Senate that when the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Gietzelt) was present I drew attention to a very considerable failure and was seeking information on that. In the past and under the Fraser Government, a major program was implemented to convert vehicles, including Commonwealth vehicles, to operate on liquefied petroleum gas in order to get fuel saving. My memory is that there was to be a target of about 3,000 vehicles a year. The answer to me in the Estimates Committee was:

SPEECH.PARA: Currently the Commonwealth departmental fleet has 144 LPG-powered vehicles out of an estimated total of 15,300. The major statutory authorities operate 417 out of an estimated total of 31,000.

It goes on to say that the taxi fleets, which understand the economics of this matter, have converted very fully and that in Adelaide, Melbourne and Brisbane taxi industry sources estimate over 90 per cent of the taxis are LPG fuelled. Sydney and Perth fleets are undergoing conversion with current levels of 56 per cent and 50 per cent respectively. It is expected that these levels will rise to those obtained in other capitals within five years. About 55 per cent of the Tasmanian taxi fleet is LPG fuelled; in Canberra, it is 98 per cent. Against that background, the government policy was to pursue the targets I have indicated in the hope that in a decade or so some 14 per cent of automotive fuel would be provided by LPG. I draw the Minister's attention to the report in the Estimates:
However, it is estimated that in 1983-84 LPG displaced 2.1 per cent of the motor spirit market and that around 40,000 vehicles were LPG fuelled.
The simple fact of the matter is that the whole gearing of the LPG program was aimed to give automotive use high priority against the day when the oil supplies would fall in sufficiency.

I pointed out to the other Minister that evidence had been given before the Senate of a very likely fall, over the next seven years, of self-sufficiency, possibly down to as low as 42 per cent, unless there are significant oil finds, and that we are using more oil than we are finding. I am relating it to the item on energy conservation, where, as my figures show, there has been a marked failure in the programs, and I seek the Minister's comment on the matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —Regarding the disparity between some vehicles in the private sector and government vehicles, there is, I think, a partial explanation for that. Because of the exemption from the refined petroleum excise for LPG, there is some incentive for operators of vehicles in the private sector-provided that they have a high mileage and access to LPG supplies, and so on-to convert. This incentive is not really present with the government fleet because it is an internal transaction, essentially, so far as the Government as a whole is concerned.

SPEECH.PARA: On the broader question, it would appear that the targets which had been set down at the time that Senator Sir John Carrick was the responsible Minister would not be met. I am not so sure that that is a matter for concern. Both LPG and crude oil are internationally tradeable commodities, and the choice of whether one or the other should be taken is ultimately, I think, a question of the relative prices. But I shall see whether Senator Gareth Evans, when he returns, has anything to add to that, and, if so, supply it to Senator Sir John Carrick.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I may direct my remarks to the Minister. I do not think it is fair to talk about the absence of excise at the Commonwealth level as being a disincentive. I suggest that the way to achieve a program of energy conservation in the Commonwealth Government is to give an instruction and to see that it is carried out. Quite clearly, if, in fact, the total conversion is 144 vehicles no such instruction has been given, and certainly nothing has been carried out. So, fundamentally, that comparison on excise is non-existent. If the Minister sees the problem as being one simply of cost, and not of conservation, I suggest to him, as kindly as I can, that that is not what I am asking. We are dealing with energy conservation. Equally, as the Minister must know, whereas Australia has abundant gas supplies and a possibility of converting even natural gas in that regard, and whereas it has very perilous supplies of oil, the problem of conversion is that one would have to start now if in seven years one were to have a fleet that had saved appreciably, 10 per cent to 14 per cent. I ask the Minister to get a response from the responsible Minister along those lines.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will ask the Minister for Resources and Energy to comply with Senator Sir John Carrick's last request. I do not want to start a debate on the conservation argument but, if that argument is followed a couple of steps further down the logical path that has been laid down, it could be used as a criticism of the Government's present policy of exporting crude oil. Some people criticise that policy but, to my knowledge, it is not seriously disputed by the Opposition. I think judgments are involved here. In this area, as in many other areas, the present Government has decided on policies which are more closely related to allowing market forces to determine what happens rather than Government directives.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister would not have had the opportunity of looking at questions asked at the Estimates committee meeting where we sought information concerning energy conservation in government buildings and a series of tables was supplied. The claim before the Estimates committee was that there had been a considerable success. The fact of the matter is that if one looks at the electricity bills one by one, year by year-there are two or three years of comparisons-one sees that there is little or no evidence at all of any real conservation. This ought to appeal to the Minister's heart, as Minister for Finance, as not just tens of millions of dollars but hundreds of millions of dollars in energy bills could be saved. For example, in 1983-84 the electricity bill for the Edmund Barton building was $335,000, rising to $414,000-odd the following year, and so the statistics continue in very big figures right throughout.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple fact of the matter is that this will mean not only a saving of money for the Government through good housekeeping but also, above everything else, that we will be using electricity to the best possible advantage. A policy for energy conservation in government buildings has been set out. The Minister will know that in the early 1980s there was a chronic shortage of electric power in New South Wales and Victoria-the two States that are of significance to the Australian Capital Territory. That, allied with a drought, caused very severe blackouts and restrictions on industry. The best way to build a power house is to save the equivalent of a power house in terms of energy conservation. That makes sense in every respect in terms of government savings. The general feeling throughout the world is that if one is willing to do this kind of thing a saving of up to 30 per cent on energy costs can be achieved, and that represents a saving for the Government of hundreds of millions of dollars. The same thing applies to the automotive industry.

I simply draw attention to these figures. I recognise that the Minister would not have seen them and, therefore, it would be wrong for me to seek clarification. I just wish to draw attention to the whole situation. If we are to tackle Australia's greatest problem and get productivity up and internal costs down, if we are to conserve energy so that we have more electric power for the future without more capitalisation of power stations, if we are to have more automotive power without having to import oil, this makes good sense. Those figures show some progress but not much.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can only agree with most of what Senator Sir John Carrick has said. It has been demonstrated that investment in building retrofits has been extremely cost effective. From memory, capital pay-back periods are as short as 18 months. I think the planning for a program of retrofitting was done when Senator Sir John Carrick was the Minister responsible and it was continued in the two Budgets with which I was associated in the Department of Resources and Energy. In the present Budget, $1.5m has been appropriated in the estimates of the Department of Housing and Construction for the modification of Commonwealth buildings for energy conservation.

—I wish to ask the Minister a question in relation to the export of crude oil from Bass Strait. Reference was made to this at the Estimates committee meeting. On what grounds was the decision taken to allow the export of crude oil two years ago? Is there a ceiling on the amount of oil that can be exported in a year? Is this subject to revision in any way at all? What amount of money do we earn in export earnings and what percentage of Australia's export earnings this year comes from the export of crude oil?

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Mininster for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot guarantee the precision of some of the answers that I will give. Senator MacGibbon asked for the reasons for the Government's decision. I was the Minister responsible at the time and I can give him some of them. Foremost amongst those reasons was that if oil production were locked in in Bass Strait or, indeed, anywhere else for want of a market it is reasonable to assume, and the Government made the judgment, that that would have a depressing effect on oil exploration activity. Senator MacGibbon asked whether there was any ceiling on the amount of crude oil that can be exported. The answer is no, there is no ceiling per se, but the Government monitors the prices at which oil is exported. As to the revenue earned from oil exports, I am fairly uncertain but from memory it was of the order of $1.7 billion in the last financial year. However, it ought to be borne in mind that Australia is still a significant net importer of oil.
—I am aware of that, but what percentage would that be of our export earnings? Would it be 10 per cent, 30 per cent or 2 per cent?
—If my figure of $1.7 billion is correct, it is of the order of 4 or 5 per cent.

—I rise as a result of the eloquence of Senator Sir John Carrick earlier on the subject of water, which is a subject quite dear to my heart. It raised a number of unanswered questions for me. I would like to know how the Government is planning to develop and handle this very important area. What appropriation is being made available to look at new developments for water conservation and water reticulation in Australia, in particular for imaginative projects such as the Clarence River hydro-electric scheme which has been promoted to me by a number of councils along the River Murray? I ask the Minister: What are the Government's current plans and what funds are being made available to look at our needs in the year 2000? How many of the plans that have been put forward are actually being put into practice?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance and Acting Minister for Resources and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is very much more a policy question than an Estimates committee question. I do not know whether this matter was taken up at an Estimates committee meeting itself. There is, of course, and there has been for many years, a water resources assessment program and a water research program, the expenditure on which amounts to just over $1m in the present Budget. Senator Vigor mentioned the Clarence River, which I presume is in northern New South Wales. I think he called it a hydro-electric scheme. From what I recall of that proposition, it involves pumping water uphill, thereby consuming electricity, instead of generating electricity by putting it though a turbine as it goes downhill. As far as I know, that proposal is not under any study at the moment. If that is wrong-I would be be surprised if it were wrong-I will ask the Minister for Resources and Energy to let the honourable senator know.

SPEECH.PARA: Proposed expenditure agreed to.
Department of the Special Minister of State
Proposed expenditure, $243,624,000

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the matter of the account rendered by the Department of the Special Minister of State to the organisers of the World Cup Athletics. It was for a considerable amount of money, alleged to be the cost of policing provided at the World Cup Athletics. Has that account been paid or does it remain with the organisers of the World Cup Athletics as an account which is expected to be paid by them?
—If I heard the question properly, Senator Reid asked whether the account in question has been paid. I am advised that the answer is no.
—Is it still outstanding and expected to be paid?
—I would assume so.

—Can the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) tell us the basis of the account, how it was calculated and in particular on what basis an account was rendered to this organisation? What accounts will be rendered to other organisations where police are involved? Can we have a specific set of rules or regulations so that we know exactly what the position will be for the future? For example, will such accounts apply to sporting bodies, to demonstrations-who falls foul of this and who does not?

—I am advised that the account was rendered principally for police services in the policing of the World Cup Athletics. I understand that it is the first time such an account has been rendered in the Australian Capital Teritory but it is quite common for State police departments to make similar charges where special services are requested of State police forces.

—I appreciate that it was the first time such an account had been rendered in the Australian Capital Territory; that is why I want to know in what circumstances such an account will be rendered. How are we to know in future who will get an account, maybe just a few weeks before an event, for a large sum of money? This account, if it was going to be levied, should have been, or at least could have been, made known to the organisers some three years or more previously. What are the rules?

—In the case of the World Cup Athletics there was a specific Government decision that charges would be levied for the services requested. The on-going question concerning the circumstances under which charges for services of that type will be levied is still under consideration.
—When was the decison made that this charge would be levied?
—August 1984.

—When will we know exactly who in future will be charged? There are events coming up in Canberra associated with Australia Day activities. Are these charges to be levied in this coming year or not? What about the Canberra Festival activities in March, and what about demonstrations and sporting events? How do we know which sporting events will be sent an account on the eve of the event, after all the budgeting has been done, and which ones will not?

—No answer is available at this stage but I will see that the question is drawn to the attention of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) to see whether he can give an answer as to when the guidelines or a statement of continuing policy can be expected.

—I hope that that is the case because I raised these very matters in the adjournment debate a few weeks ago and so far I have had no response. I hope that I can rely on the Minister's word that my query will be answered quite soon.
—I said I will ask him; I did not guarantee that he would answer.

—I could not find in the estimates where the cost of the Coastal Surveillance Unit was brought to charge. Formerly it was under the Australian Federal Police, yet division 577, subdivision 2, does not seem specifically to bring that to account this year. I am referring to the coastal surveillance flights operated by Skywest Aviation (Queensland) Limited.
—I will take that on notice for the time being. I may be able to supply an answer in a few minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to division 577, dealing with the Australian Federal Police. First of all I commend the Australian Federal Police for the work they have done in recent times and the significant successes they have had recently, particularly in relation to drug trafficking. I am aware that they are still a relatively small force which has had only a limited time to receive expert training. I pay my personal tribute to a force which is growing in efficiency and in achievement. When I look at the estimate I see that the amount of money allocated to the Australian Federal Police is up by barely 5 per cent. If one were to apply to administrative expenses and other things the ordinary consumer price index increases in fact there would be no growth at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I make a number of general remarks concerning the Australian Federal Police and subdivision 582, dealing with royal commissions. Recently a former royal commissioner, Mr Justice Athol Moffitt, has written a book. His report in the 1970s was virtually the first of the royal commissions into gambling, drugs and general vice. Subsequently there have been the Woodward, Williams, Costigan and Stewart royal commissions-indeed I may have left out one or two-and a great volume of evidence of organised crime has emerged. I hope that the Government and the authorities within the operations of the Government-the police, the Stewart Royal Commission of Inquiry into Drug Trafficking and the National Crime Authority-will seek to investigate the key findings and the key comments of each of those commissions. One tends in politics to deal episodically with things as they arise. I am suggesting that here now is, probably uniquely, a collection of experience, evidence and facts from five royal commissions. Here too now is a book published by a very distinguished Australian, a man who has deliberately not sought to write headlines in his book but has pointed to events and trends of events rather than name individuals just to chase headlines.

I commend to each of the authorities concerned not only an examination of the book but also a willingness on its part to seek out persons such as Mr Justice Athol Moffitt, interview them and seek from them the magnificent wealth of experience that they have gained. I know the kind of people they are and they would be very willing to be forthcoming. I would like to see a study done by the Government and its authorities of the whole of these reports, not in detail of individual alleged villains or, indeed, of individual events but to establish a pattern from which we can get a blueprint of what is happening in Australia. The Moffitt Royal Commission first drew attention to the fact that there was an emergence of organised crime, particularly of blue collar crime, of a magnitude quite different from anything we had seen before. I am not sure that governments of all persuasions have been alert enough to deal with it.

I rise tonight to commend the Federal Police, to draw attention to some new information and to invite the Government to look at the information, from wherever it may come, and extract from it the key evidence. This would be helpful to all honourable senators in contemplating the future, in contemplating for example the work which the National Crime Authority should undertake. It would be helpful not simply to look at individual cases, but to look at patterns as they have been drawn up by the Royal Commissions. I invite the Government to do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator MacGibbon, the total cost of the coastal protection unit's program is $33.4m, most of which-$21.5m-is appropriated within the Department of Defence and most of which involves contract services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Following the Minister's reply, the Committee will remember that when the contract was first let to Skywest Airlines Ltd, the circumstances in which it was awarded came under considerable criticism in the Senate. One of the elements of that criticism was the fitting of sideways looking radar in the Shrike Commander aircraft which I said was an absolute nonsense and subsequent events have proved the correctness of that. This radar has now been withdrawn from service. The Ericsson sideways looking radar was a secondary surveillance radar which was designed for detecting oil slicks and icebergs in the North Sea, neither of which are terribly common occurances on the Barrier Reef.
—Or the north coast.

—Or the north coast, as Senator Kilgariff says. Yet this was its primary role. I would like to know how much money we lost on that nonsensical exercise which the Department and the Minister would not be told was futile before it was introduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The operator has now leased for a trial period a maritime version of a King Air aircraft which has a much better radar fitted in it. What is this lease costing us? If it is successful, will the aircraft be bought by Skywest and a lease agreement entered into for the Commonwealth to provide this surveillance of the Barrier Reef area? Above all, who will make the judgment? Will the same bunch of people who made the judgment that the Ericsson was suitable, be the people who will now sit in judgment on the King Air or will some competent people be doing it?

TALK.START.PARA: —Like you?
—Well, I could do a lot better than they did.
—I do not have any information on those questions but I will see whether the Special Minister of State, Mr Young, has any information that he can supply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct the Committee's attention to Division 580 which deals with the Australian Electoral Commission. I am one of the members of the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform and I acknowledge that a considerable amount of progress has been made both in the establishment of the Commission and in legislative reform. But fundamentally the mechanisms of electoral reform will fail essentially for one government budgetary reason. All the elements are built around the fact that an electoral roll must be clean. The Government has not made any money available at all for a habitation review this year. It is a nonsense to set up an electoral commission, to give it the job of cleansing the rolls-making transfers, wiping out those people who have died and adding new people-if it cannot do one fundamental thing. This is doubly important. It is no use the Minister saying: `We have a three-year cycle; we can do it before an election or before the next shower of rain'. The fact is that the Government is rightly seeking to get an agreement with all States that there be a joint preparation of rolls and that the rolls be joint rolls. I think that only one State, or at the most two, now stand out. If a roll is to be in reasonable condition for any State election or for a Federal election whenever it may emerge, there must be a continuous habitation review and a continuous cleansing of the rolls so that both the States and the Commonwealth can have available a set of facts.

SPEECH.PARA: I was recently taken to see a demonstration of a pilot computer program that would do marvellous things if one had the millions of dollars to buy it. It can make sure that if somebody dies he or she is taken out of the roll and if somebody transfers somewhere that is noted on the rolls. The only trouble was that I asked a question that one should not ask-how one could tell whether the basic roll was clean. How does one check up ab initio on a person who is initially enrolled? There is absolutely no check at all. It is like expertly shuffling a crook pack of cards. Therefore, it is an absolute nonsense to set up mechanisms and for Senator Ray and me to come into this Parliament and talk about the virtues of how a redistribution is done. If we do a redistribution over seven years, we lock it in and we have a median point at three and a half years for a precise figure. At this moment we are very worried about whether there should be any tolerance at all. This is the essence of lunacy because one starts off with a gross error. We are playing silly little people's games. We are pretending to the community that a system is correct and accurate when in fact the very basis from which we start is not accurate.

I say emphatically that there is no sense in pretending that we have a basis of a sound electoral system particularly if we have joint Federal and State rolls if we will not make money available for habitation reviews. It is no use the Government saying that it might do it next year after or in the year before an election. Habitation reviews must be done continously in order to meet the demands of all States. It is nonsense to think of computerising rolls and shuffling the pack accurately when the pack itself is defective. I make the strong plea to the Minister that whatever the economies may be, the money must be allocated. One cannot have an effective parliamentary system with redistribution unless one's rolls are honest. At this moment the rolls are getting more and more erroneous, both for State and Federal purposes. Therefore, while commending the work of the Committee and the chairmanship of Senator Robert Ray, I must say that there is a fundamental error in the budgeting of a government which seeks not to cut the amount for a habitation review but to provide no money at all for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a sad day when I have to get up here and agree with Senator Sir John Carrick. I think that the Government will have to give consideration to how it funds habitation reviews. The current Act says that every two years there will be a habitation review. I have some doubts whether that is sufficient on two grounds. The first is whether it is fair. I suspect the Australian Labor Party does better out of annual habitation reviews than biannual ones because our voters tend to be on the move far more than Liberal voters. Therefore, I think in our own self-interest we may have to look at annual habitation reviews. Secondly, I know that no government likes to tie in an annual expendure item that it always has to pay out. No Finance Minister, no Treasurer, has any particular liking for that. We have spent a lot more on making Australia a democratic community in the last three years. We have set up the Australian Electoral Commission; we have introduced public funding and introduced a whole range of reforms. Senator Sir John Carrick is right that if the basic building blocks are not there, a lot of those reforms become farcical. If this Government wanted to learn a lesson about roll habitation, it had only to look at the role of the previous Government, which was very tardy in this particular exercise. It seemed to have habitation reviews in Labor electorates but never in National Party electorates. When we talk about a clean roll, the one thing we do not do is cut off the roll the moment an election is announced and disfranchise a couple of hundred thousand people. Apart from those minor disagreements with Senator Sir John Carrick, I think he is basically right. That is the price of democracy. It will probably cost $2m to $3m a year and it is unavoidable.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —My temporary love affair with Senator Robert Ray has to have a minor aberration at this moment. He suggests that some act of ministerial authority has brought about a situation where politically rolls were cleansed in one area and not in another. That is a gross reflection on the Commonwealth electoral officers and the divisional electoral officers at the time. I just happen to know that it is not true.
—Have a look at the answer to Senator Gietzelt's question in 1981.

—If Senator Ray gives it to me, I will look at it. I simply want to say that it ought not to be a habit in this place to suggest that a Commonwealth electoral officer is corrupt. He can only do this if he is carrying out orders. I for one do not suggest that the Hawke Labor Government is giving political orders to the Australian Electoral Commission. I believe that if money is made available for roll cleansing it will be made available on the basis of a Commonwealth chief electoral officer receiving information from his divisional electoral officers and acting accordingly. I simply rise to correct that. I think in his heart or hearts Senator Robert Ray will smile and agree with me.

—The fact is that when the Government allows only 50 per cent of the money to an electoral office for a habitation review-that is a government decision-it inevitably picks inner city areas or suburban areas because they can be done quickly, easily and cheaply. The effect of that was that the National Party areas were not hit. Only Labor electorates and, indeed, some Liberal electorates were hit, but the National Party electorates were not hit. We have to question how much advantage that was to the National Party.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to rake over any sordid coals, as Senator Robert Ray was about to do. Senator Sir John Carrick is right in the sense that the rolls are inaccurate the day after they are compiled. There is a continuing accumulation of-I was going to say dead wood-a dead something or other on the rolls which requires review. I am advised that the position so far as Senator Sir John Carrick's point of substance is concerned is that this year a habitation review is being conducted in Western Australia to which the Commonwealth has contributed some $95,000. The current legislation requires a habitation review every two years. It is expected that there will be a need to budget for about $4,500m next year for the purpose of habitation reviews. As Senator Sir John Carrick acknowledged, the legislation prescribes a two-year habitation review. It is understood that the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform will again be considering whether to recommend annual reviews as distinct from two-yearly reviews. Any change in the legislation will, of course, wait on any such recommendation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister. I simply remind him-he perhaps needs no reminding-that what has changed is the joint rolls. As more and more States take the Commonwealth rolls, it is quite clear that every year the rolls have got to be as accurate as possible because there will always be a State or Federal election. I simply ask the Minister to take that aboard for the future.
—That is a view that could appropriately be put to the Joint Select Committee on Electoral Reform.

—I would like to touch, very briefly, on coastal surveillance. The viability and efficiency of the coastal protection unit has been a rather controversial matter. I understand that, to a degree, it comes under the jurisdiction of the Special Minister of State (Mr Young). To bring an end to the controversy, is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) in a position to indicate whether it is correct that the flying hours and the finance available for the Shrike aircraft-that is the coastal surveillance aircraft under charter-have been cut back? Is it also correct that charter aircraft emanating out of Darwin are now making fewer flights along the northern coast?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that there is a reduced requirement from the Department of Health and accordingly, the number of hours available has been reduced. I think I can fairly remind Senator Kilgariff that this has been the subject matter of a question in the Senate. I will endeavour to obtain the answer, which gives much more detailed information than I am able to provide at the moment. The honourable senator's question was whether the hours have been reduced. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has indicated that the finance for the Department of Health has been cut back. As I understand it, coastal surveillance, quarantine matters and the like do come under the Department of Health. It is very difficult to ascertain within the Budget Papers whether the same amount of money is being spent each year on coastal surveillance because it is so fragmented over the various departments. When the Minister obtains this information, will he ascertain whether coastal surveillance as a whole is being cut back? If this is the case, it is difficult to understand the reason. There has been a drive by the Federal Government this year in relation to the prevention of drug abuse. The project is called Operation Noah. I commend the authorities for previously conducting such a drive because they were able to obtain information which resulted in finding millions of dollars worth of drugs that were brought into Australia. I thought that was extremely good. I have no doubt that people who are interested in drug prevention would commend the authorities for their initiative.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I am making now is that a lot of drugs are brought into the country from the Golden Triangle in Indo-China. Operation Noah was to encourage the Australian community to lend its assistance to finding the smugglers and bringing about their apprehension. In view of that it is most unusual that funding for northern coastal surveillance is being cut back. The Minister has yet to confirm this. To me, that is a most serious situation. Frankly, I think that this is extremely poor economy, given the inroads that drugs are making into Australia now. As I have said, the fragmentation of budgeting for northern surveillance, which covers so many departments, causes a most difficult problem. I look to the Minister to give the chamber, Australia and me an assurance that northern surveillance is not being cut back; that it is being kept up in an efficient unit and that funds are being made available to the coastal protection unit to ensure that it operates efficiently.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Kilgariff asked me, in conjunction with other information I have said will be obtained, to obtain some information about this matter. I said earlier that the requirement in respect of health, which is a quarantine function as I understand it, had gone down. The overall expenditure on surveillance this year has gone up moderately-by $1.6m. I do not know whether any amount of expenditure on this initiative will give Senator Kilgariff or anybody else the assurance he requires in respect of the potential for importation of drugs into Australia, but that may be some small satisfaction. I will endeavour to obtain the other information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Department of the Special Minister of State provides some of the facilities and resources for members of parliament. The parliamentary departments, of course, supply the others. The Department of the Special Minister of State supplies resources for electorate offices for senators and members. The Department of the Senate supplies equipment for senators' offices in Canberra. A situation has arisen where the Department of the Senate has moved senators into the twentieth century with the provision of computers for use in their parliamentary offices. That equipment has been provided through the Department of the Senate under its appropriation. The question now arises as to what will happen in relation to the provision of equipment in electorate offices for senators and members. What has been spoken of, apparently, is that the Department of the Special Minister of State may be moving independently along some path to provide computers in some electorate offices.

SPEECH.PARA: There are some problems. Firstly, those parliamentarians who use this modern word processing or data processing equipment have a requirement for it in both their electorate offices and their parliamentary offices. I have four such machines-one in Parliament, two in my electorate office and one at home-to enable me to do the kind of work I need to do. Now that many other parliamentarians are acquiring such equipment in their electorate offices, it is quite likely that the Department of the Special Minister of State will want to go down that path. As far as we are concerned, we have one job to do and it does not matter whether the equipment is provided by one or other department. What matters is that we should have equipment which is compatible and can be used in both places, so that we can use modem connections to get the machines talking to each other.

It is not clear what are the intentions of the Department of the Special Minister of State in this area. Will there be a move to provide this kind of equipment for parliamentarians and can we be certain that interdepartmental rivalries will not lead us to a situation where equipment obtained for the electorate offices either is not compatible with that in the parliamentary offices or in some other way is not developed in an integrated fashion? It would be a gross waste of resources if the departments failed to work together on the provision of computers to parliamentarians. I hope that commonsense will prevail and the same equipment is purchased. The Department of the Senate, for example, has chosen equipment from Digital Equipment Corporation (Aust.) Pty Ltd for honourable senators. I hope that a decision taken by the Department of the Special Minister of State will not see some machinery chosen which is not compatible with that which has been chosen by the Department of the Senate. I would like the Minister to advise us of what steps are being taken by the Department of the Special Minister of State in relation to developments in this area. What assurance can he give us that it will be integrated in every possible way with the work being carried on in the parliamentary departments?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Peter Baume is correct in saying that there has been some interest in this matter. The Department of the Special Minister of State appointed a group of consultants specialising in office equipment and micro-processing tech- nology to look into the matter. The group reported to the Special Minister of State (Mr Young) on 19 November, seven days ago.
—Who were they?
—I do not know. The question of compatibility, of course, had to be addressed in any such study. I think that the Department is as aware as he or I of the importance of it.

—I have several questions relating to the Australian Federal Police, which I understand is handled by the Special Minister of State. On page 847 of the Hansard of Estimates Committee E it was stated that probably no police force in Australia is currently researching computer fraud as such. No estimate could be given at the time of the cost to the community of computer fraud. What types of measures does the Government intend to take to make it harder for people to perpetrate swindles in this area and to handle the problems of companies and government bodies which may be subject to hackers or people who can get into computers and modify figures to their own advantage or to the advantage of an organisation to which they belong?
—Haven't you heard of Estimates committees or questions on notice, or are you just trying to be difficult?
—This is a very important estimate.
—Of course it is important; everything is important. That is why we have Estimates committees, questions on notice and adjournment debates. You are just being a nuisance.
—I will sit down to give Senator Button a chance to answer my question.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State has already announced, I understand, a decision to have a study made of a variety of forms of fraud, including computer fraud. —I have a question on the matter of electoral reform. TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise tonight the question of human rights which has received considerable publicity in relation to the activities of a group of eminent persons, which includes a former Prime Minister of this country, which has been appointed to take steps to endeavour to ensure the protection of human rights and development of full human rights in South Africa. Bearing in mind that persons's activities and interest in relation to South Africa, I remind the Senate of his interest and activities in relation to another country-Afghanistan-and of what is being done in relation to it by the world, by this Parliament and by the person to whom I refer, the Rt Hon. Malcolm Fraser. Malcolm Fraser was sufficiently concerned, and still is concerned, about South Africa and Zimbabwe to be involved in a great number of discussions and actions taken in regard to South Africa. He was also sufficiently concerned about Afghanistan to suggest that Australians should not participate in the Olympic Games which were to be held in Moscow, thereby not encouraging the Russian invasion of Afghanistan.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a matter of some concern that the invasion of Afghanistan appears to have been forgotten in the welter of words about actions being taken in relation to southern Africa. I remind the Senate that on 19 February 1985 the European Commission on Human Rights reported to the United Nations Economic and Social Council on Afghanistan. It made horrendous findings about the actions of the `Government' of and invading forces in Afghanistan. By way of background I refer to the fact that at the first regular session in 1984 of the Economic and Social Council of the United Nations the Council, by its resolution No. 37 of 1984 entitled `Situation of Human Rights in Afghanistan', endorsed by 35 votes to four, with 12 abstentions, the Commission's decision to request the Chairman of the Commission on Human Rights to appoint a Special Rapporteur with the mandate to examine the human rights situation in Afghanistan, with a view to formulating proposals which could contribute to ensuring full protection of the human rights of all residents of the country before, during and after the withdrawal of all foreign forces. The resolution is set out in the report to which I have referred.

What that report describes is quite horrific. I am not suggesting that what it describes is peculiar. Regrettably, war brings with it not only the deprivation of human rights but also the degradation of human beings. It brings with it the degradation of the standards of behaviour of the winners or oppressors. It brings with it the deprivation of the rights of those who are subjected to being on the losing end of the power struggle at a particular time.

TALK.START.PARA: —As sinners we look the other way.

—I thank Senator Kilgariff for his comment. I briefly draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that the United Nations report referred to the use of anti-personnel mines and so-called toy bombs. It referred to the victimisation of the civilian population-I emphasise this-particularly of women and children. It referred to the non-acceptance of members of the Afghan opposition forces as prisoners of war. The report, in its recommendations, referred to the desirability that the governments directly involved in the present situation regarding human rights in Afghanistan should co-operate fully with the United Nations, in particular in clarifying the fate of missing persons, and should do everything possible, as a matter of urgency, to contribute to the restoration and upholding of human rights in Afghanistan.

SPEECH.PARA: The report referred to the fact that Soviet forces had engaged in a deliberate policy of bombing villages, massacring civilians and summarily executing captured guerrillas. The report accused the Government of Afghanistan of holding an estimated 50,000 political prisoners. We hear about South Africa. We hear about what is wrong in South Africa. I do not wish to debate that or to suggest that some of the things which have been happening in South Africa are not wrong. But let us keep these things in balance. When we are talking about and paying attention to human rights in the world, let us keep in balance the allegation made in a report of the Commission on Human Rights that there are 50,000 political prisoners in Afghanistan.

I pause to say that a Scandinavian report of some two years ago alleged that there were of the order of 200,000 political prisoners in Vietnam. What have we heard about those people? What have we heard about the 50,000 political prisoners in Afghanistan? The report said that torture in gaols had become so routine that it had assumed the character of an `administrative practice'. The report was prepared by an Austrian law professor, Felix Ermacora. It is not regarded as being political from the point of view of being biased in regard to political parties. Professor Ermacora had also participated in human rights inquiries into Chile and South Africa.

It is interesting to note that the Afghan Government refused to co-operate with Professor Ermacora when undertaking his report. His report referred to the fact that not only was torture and ill-treatment inflicted on women but also degrading treatment was undergone by many of them. The Special Rapporteur took particular note of cases of women who had been raped in the presence of members of their families. One witness mentioned the case of one Said Rafik, who was killed by soldiers because he had intervened to prevent his daughter from being raped by a soldier. In his testimony, a former officer of the security police stated that he himself had witnessed the scene-the report references where it occurred-where a husband had been obliged to watch the rape of his wife who was eight months pregnant. Numerous witnesses declared that children had been seriously wounded, having their hands and feet blown off either by handling `booby-trapped toys' picked up along the roadway or by stepping on them. According to witnesses these toys had been dropped by helicopter into zones presumed to be occupied by the resistance. The booby-trap toys, which exploded on the slightest contact, were shaped like pens or small animals and looked completely inoffensive from the outside.

I could go on to quote a great deal about the use of poisonous gases and reprisals for alleged acts of terrorism. I could quote the detail of the report. It is not my intention tonight to quote the report in full. I am trying to say that this Parliament, while considering its concern for human rights in the world, should keep that question in balance. We must bear in mind that some three million Afghans have fled Afghanistan as a result of the Russian invasion and that more than one million are estimated to have been killed.

TALK.START.PARA: —And that is conservative.
—I thank the honour- able senator. That is a conservative estimate.
—That is another independent rapporteur that you have there-Senator Kilgariff.

—Senator Kilgariff is another concerned Australian and not someone who makes supercilious comments about a matter of great seriousness. I do not propose to be interrupted by somebody who regards with flippancy the serious matter to which I am trying to direct myself. I wish to go on to refer briefly to some of the other areas of concern in relation to the question of human rights to which I believe regard should be paid. One country that concerns me is Romania. A report by the Department of State submitted to the Committee on Foreign Relations in the United States Senate and the Committee on Foreign Affairs in the United States House of Representatives, dated February 1985, states with regard to Romania:

SPEECH.PARA: In the area of human rights, major discrepancies persist between Romania's Constitution, laws, Public pronouncements, and international commitments on the one hand, and the civil liberties and human rights actually allowed by the regime on the other. Almost all aspects of life proceed within narrow bounds defined by authority without regard to constitutional and legal guarantees, although practices vary as a result of individual circumstances and attitudes of local officials. Political dissent is not tolerated; any appearance of deviation from the party's policies is actively repressed. Psychological and, to a lesser extent, physical intimidation by the ubiquitous security apparatus and other state organs is effective in securing conformity, although the costs in terms of individual liberties, creativity, and overall economic efficiency are apparent.
The report talks about political killings, torture and cruel, inhuman or degrading treatment and punishment. It states:

There have been numerous reports of cruel and degrading treatment in Romanian prisons in 1984. The most common complaints concern cells which are badly ventilated and poorly heated, bad food in extremely small quantities, difficult working conditions, long periods of isolation, little or no reading materials, overcrowding, and segregation of persons deemed ``dangerous to the State'' because of their religious beliefs. Furthermore, persons convicted of political crimes are not allowed to work but are forced to spend their sentences within the confines of the prison, thus forgoing the possibility of reducing their sentences through work outside the prison. Acts of violence perpetrated by police authorities attempting to obtain information are commonly reported. Persons apprehended for illegally trying to cross the border often complain of cruel treatment, including beatings, inflicted during police custody. Persons detained for questioning are often kept for long periods without sleep, food, or toilet facilities.

The report goes on to talk about arbitrary arrest, the denial of fair public trial, the denial of freedom of speech and freedom of the Press. It goes on to talk about the denial of freedom of peaceful assembly and association and, in particular, it talks about the fact that free trade unions are not permitted. I have no doubt that that is a matter which would concern those who believe that a free trade union movement is an important part of a democracy. The report talks about the limitations on freedom of religion and states that only certain religions are recognised. It states:

During 1984, fewer cases of harassment were reported, although the persecution of members of denominations not recognized by the State, such as Jehovah's Witnesses, Mormons, Christian Scientists, and Romanian Uniates continues. Individuals are still fined and imprisoned for religious practices.

This is the sort of world with which we should be concerned. This is the sort of world which we tend to forget, I believe, when we concentrate our attention on what is going wrong in one area and pretend that our efforts ought to be concentrated and limited to that one area alone.

An item which appeared in a newspaper on 30 October concerned me greatly when I read it. I think it sums up what I am talking about. I do not remember any great world outrage when it was reported that 200 political prisoners were excuted in Iran during the month of October, according to a communique issued in Paris by the Islamic left movement People's Mujahedeen. That event was just accepted as deserving a small three or four-line paragraph in a newspaper and apparently is not regarded as a matter of great moment.

But one single country has been singled out by a large number of people in the world as being one upon which they will concentrate because they have some reason for wishing to do so. A committee of eminent persons has been established to look into the question of human rights of individuals in that country. What about the other countries of the world with which we should be concerned? What about the political prisoners in Iran? What about the political prisoners and human rights in Romania? What about the millions of people who have been affected by the Russian invasion of Afghanistan? When will we pay a little more attention to them?

I recall that when I was in Bonn in 1978 I met one of the Indian members of parliament who had been imprisoned under the regime of Indira Gandhi, a person whom I regarded at that time as being a dictator. He said to me that whilst he was in prison under her regime, a copy of the speeches which had been made in this chamber by certain of us who were concerned about the political prisoners in India at that time had been smuggled in. He said how much it meant to him to have smuggled to him whilst in prison the expressions of concern and to know of the pressure which was being applied in a free democracy towards the restoration of democracy and freedom in a country in which at that time he happened to be a member of parliament imprisoned for his political beliefs.

I ask the Senate tonight to bear in mind that if we raise these questions they can sometimes do some good. They can sometimes bring home to the regimes which are inflicting a deprivation of human rights the pressure which is necessary to reduce the degree of deprivation or possibly even restore human rights in those countries. It is in that light that I have made my comments-in the hope that we may get from the Government an assurance that it will pass on to the governments of those countries the views of this chamber, of this Parliament and of this country that human rights are to be respected, that we believe that human rights are universal and not selective and that we believe that human rights might be enforced in those countries through pressure from all of those sections of the world which are free to enjoy them, and that includes Australia. I trust that we will get from this Government an assurance that it will do everything it can to see human rights preserved and asserted in every country of the world and not selectively in some parts of it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 10.50 p.m.
